SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the PIONEER

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The best thing to do is to answer those questions which apply to you and leave the rest blank.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether or not they were born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family own answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Westerbom Consider? Pioneer Saskatchewan" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this question, we would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

Pioneer health conditions
Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
Pioneer housing
Pioneer education and employment
Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Branch Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924 and may be answered by persons who have personal experience of the pioneer years whether or not they have been in this province or not.

Had only one child, James Cameron who lives there.

Purchased 80 acres in Homelton, Ontario 8 years ago.

Part of 27 years.

23. Is there any particular experiences of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to report?

While on Construction work on R.R. M.P. arrived at our Camp with a warrant for the owner of our land, Mr. W. J. Smith.

In charge of the Office and the Camp for Mr. Smith.

I went to his Bullen's and often on this trip I thought he was our Prince of the few names I knew.

I was finally able to get a job at the Steamboat dinner.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Travelled in the new Railways (Canada) and by horseback.

On Half Time (working on the Canadian Pacific Railway).

The Company paid for our own Dinner Carries and every trip I applied for own Dinner Carries and every trip I took apply to all the trips. I travelled about 400 miles each trip.

We used to camp in the woods near the river.

A week by canoe, then we came to camp by horseback.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

They were very much interested in the future of the town. That was the main reason why they moved.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, two left in the 1930s as we have more people coming back now. In fact, we have had quite a few returns recently.

36. If so, what organizations did they join?

They joined the local board, the school board, and various clubs such as the Lions Club and the Elks Club.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were involved in any organizations, mention it here.

I was a member of the Lions Club and the Elks Club, and I was also involved in the local school board.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, farms, etc.)

The town was named after the first settler, Mr. Johnson. The school district was named after the first teacher, Mrs. Smith. The post office was named after the first postmaster, Mr. Brown.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1920? What reasons did they have for moving?

They went away but most of them returned.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

They moved away again as they thought that Baerwill was fading in Canada.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been a member of the local Board since 1930.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were arrested to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible (such as onlin).

I was arrested in 1930 for selling liquor.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills etc.). Try to give: (1) name; (2) date and reason for change; (3) date of its first post office; (4) any other interesting facts about the name.

Baerwill was named after Mr. Baer, who was born in Missouri and came to Canada to work at Morley Station in 1864 as an employee of the Canadian Pacific Railway Co. He purchased land in 1882 and built a homestead in this area. He died in 1900 and his family continued to live there. The name was changed from the present spelling "Baerwill" to "Baerwill" when the village was founded which means "loose" (in French). They also had a post office until this date.

Baerwill was officially on a list until 1905.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I think I could procure Diary's from different people here and photos daily days. You would be sure to retain them as they are highly prized by the owners. We had our 50th anniversary of our farm on July 15, 1932 and had an old diary book where I got 160 signatures of persons who had been here for over 50 years. I have this in my possession.

Would you or the person who owns them either

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The fine roads, the excellent buildings in both Village & Country, the production of our farms in livestock and grain and above all the community spirit of all our citizens which makes Rossville and district in my opinion the best place to live in Saskatchewan.
